Topic.Title: PCs Aren't Dying - They Are Transcending

Message.Msg: Well, that's the big question. Without a lot more detailed info, some of which is not knowable to us mortals at this moment, it is very hard to make a model of Intel revenues/margins to answer the near term transitional questions. Ashraff has done some good work there, but at a detailed level it is a process in work. Fundamentally, Intel is traditionally three large organs: (1) PC Client Group at about 70% R and (2) Servers at about 20% and (3) yes there's also "other". By itself this instructs us that a -x% reduction in PC's can be compensated by a +(7/2)x% increase in server demand. I view this is approximately a steady state at present (these two terms approximately offset one another, perhaps slightly negative based upon past few quarters), though projections for server growth are quite impressive (people talk about 12% to 16% per year). This can offset a - 3.4% to -4.5% decline in PC's, but Intel's exposure to PC decline may well be greater than that. Now throw in the 10% of "other" This may include rapidly growing components like Tablets and Smartphones. This is a tiny component of Intel's overall R at the present time, so I doubt it can compensate the first term. So, in the transition, you need to know a lot about the company. This is a very coarse grained model, and one needs to consider management of fab costs, R&D, breakout tablets from phones from PC's in detail, etc. But, in the long term, a few years out, "other" will become 50% of the revenue, Servers perhaps 40% and PC's become 10%. Overall revenue should grow significantly. The view of the analysts is that Intel is dominated by (1) PC's and the rest (2)+(3) is not presently offsetting the decline. They may be right for a quarter or two. But this in no way implies a $20 valuation on Intel, given the future outlook. And, we may find next week that they are dead wrong.

Topic.Title: Intel's tablet challenge: How Israel helped lay the foundations of its Samsung-led fightback

Message.Msg: The fruits of its labours are now beginning to show. Samsung recently introduced its Galaxy Tab 3 tablets, all of which use Intel's Clover Trail+ line of SoC processors — developed by teams led by Intel in Jerusalem. And while many devices (including those made by Apple, Qualcomm, and many others) have "Israel Inside" technology, the development of Cloverview SoC's had some unique aspects, according to Aviad Hevrony, the front end design manager for Intel Israel's Cloverview team. In an interview, Hevrony and senior members of his 100-plus Cloverview team discussed one of the biggest engineering challenges of their career: developing a chip that would allow Samsung's devices to run both Android and Windows, while supporting low power consumption and light form factors. Intel Israel has been working on SoC systems for over four years, first developing them for netbooks, a market that was quickly eclipsed by tablets, said Hevrony. "After the introduction of the iPad it was clear where the industry was going, so we began trying to develop our own SoC technology for tablets." The Israel team led the effort, with major assists from Intel teams in Bangalore in India, and Austin and Folsom in the US.

Message.Msg: Unquestionably mobile products will become an increasing share of Intel's revenue but PCs (desktops, laptops, notebooks and Ultrabooks) remain the device most use to do real work. The problem for PCs in the first half of the year is that Microsoft did nearly everything they could to kill the desktop and laptop business by forcing the Win 8 metro user interface on the traditional PC market. Message.Msg: "While TSMC has been using single-patterning lithography based on ArF immersion for the 28 nm and older processes, it will introduce a double-patterning technology, which splits the pattern pitch formed in the first lithography in half, for the 20 nm process." Topic.Title: THIRTEEN bridges in the ATOM?

Message.Msg: Yes. This issue was brought to my attention by a friend who worked on the ATOM design team. Basically, whenever the CPU issues a cycle for I/O, memory, etc, the cycle has to be claimed downstream on the bus. For instance, if you issue an I/O read, it goes out on the Front Side Bus. Because it's an I/O instruction, the north bridge passes it on because there is no I/O in the north bridge (except AGP which is a special case.) The cycle then gets sent to the south bridge. This is called a subtractive decode because the north bridge didn't claim the cycle and "subtractively," the assumption is that something downstream on the bus will claim the I/O cycle. On the south bridge, the I/O cycle can get claimed in one of several ways: 1. If there is a PCI-PCI bridge that has an I/O aperture containing the address of the I/O cycle from the CPU, the PCI bridge will claim the cycle and forward it to the next PCI bus. 2. A PCI device on the bus can claim the cycle. 3. The I/O cycle can time out and be forwarded to another bus downstream. The forwarding bus must then wait for any and all downstream buses to claim or reject the cycle. The gist of this is that for every I/O cycle that is issued, several bridges may have to arbitrate that one cycle. Now, bear in mind that I/O cycles are way, way, way, way slower than CPU cycles so in the time it takes one I/O cycle to be processed, hundreds of thousands of CPU clocks might go by and the CPU is stuck waiting for the I/O to complete. Nothing else gets done and a lot of power is wasted. It's a horrid, highly inefficient architecture.

Message.Title: Intel Corporation (INTC) Has Big Plans For Asia
Message.Msg: Intel Corporation (INTC) Has Big Plans For Asia July 9, 2013 By Aman Jain Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC) has long viewed Asia as a manufacturing hub owing to the region’s vast market and low-cost labor. But the times are changing, with the expansion of region’s talent pool, Chip powerhouse now expects Asian engineers to help design processors that will be used in smartphones, tablets and PC’s. intel logo Intel’s Malaysian Facility Currently, Asia accounts for 80 percent of the packaging and testing of Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC) products. In 1972, the chipmaker opened its first facility outside the U.S. in the northern island of Penang, Malaysia. The facility is now one of Intel’s biggest technology development centers. Intel’s Malaysia Design Centre has played an important part in the development of the fourth-generation processor known as Haswell, which was launched in June. Apart from this, the center is also supporting the development of current and future generation Clover Trail, Bay Trail and Broadwell platforms. Apart from Malaysia, Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC) has also opened centers in India, Taiwan, China and Vietnam with investments of more than $10 billion. These centers employ more than 20,000 people, which is one-fifth of the company’s total headcount. Intel’s Future Plans In a recent interview given to The Wall Street Journal, Robin Martin, vice president of Intel’s technology manufacturing group, and Christopher Kelly, head of Intel’s Malaysia Design Center, discussed the company’s plans in Asia. As per Mr. Martin, Asia is a huge market and is growing consistently. The logistics and infrastructure in the region is also improving, so “it makes sense for us to grow the seeds that we’ve sown here.” Presently, the Malaysian facility is responsible for chips used in smartphones, tablets, and SOCs (system on chips), but as the numbers grow, the company plans to rope in Vietnam because of the cost structure there. Topic.Title: THIRTEEN bridges in the ATOM?

Message.Msg: Was this the in-order Saltwell core or the out-of-order Silvermont core? 100,000 cycles at 1GHz is 100 microseconds. You can read a whole Intel SSD block into memory in that time. That timing seems to be way high. Agner Fog's Instruction Table for Atom (Saltwell) shows that an IN or OUT instruction takes 8 uops and an additional 64 from uop ROM. None of these 100,000 stalls visible on the Anandtech benchmark power graphs of the running benchmarks. If a CPU issues a IO instruction, the CPU execution will continue until there is a register scoreboard stall. That could happen but is under some control by the original software designer and the compiler used. Only a pretty inexperienced programmer would insert serializing conditions into his code. If he happened to do that AND his SW was a success, the Intel performance groups would let him know and it would be fixed. I wouldn't worry about it. It sounds like your friend was pulling your leg.

Topic.Title: THIRTEEN bridges in the ATOM?

Message.Msg: "The number 100,000 was for illustrative purposes. It demonstrates the fact that CPU speed is orders of magnitude different from I/O speeds, esp when talking to a peripheral" I just gave some actual numbers that showed that your "fact" was inaccurate. You described an IN or OUT instruction as issued by the CPU and then stirred in a description of a system level IO as it relates to the higher level system operations (disk read/write). IN or OUT instructions are probably 10x or 20x slower. On an in-order implementation CPU (Saltwell), these would be punishing. On an out-of-order implementation CPU (Silvermont), these are likely hidden and operate in parallel to other instructions. "Do you really think most software engineers know what a serializing I/O transaction is?" Many SW engineers are not aware of performance issue related to serializing instructions. The reason is that very few of them deal with code that executes those instructions. The IO instructions are isolated in kernels and drivers. SW engineers who write kernels and drivers know about them (at least the employed ones do).

Topic.Title: THIRTEEN bridges in the ATOM?

Message.Msg: CPU IO: The CPU executes IN/OUT instructions that generate control signals and transfer data IN/OUT of the CPU. These IN/OUT instructions have latencies that depend on the device that it is talking too (disk, network, screen, ...). SYSTEM IO: Several of these CPU IN/OUT instructions are executed to initiate a data transfer from/to a PCI device. If the PCI device is a block device, the data transfer from/to that PCI block device is transferred to/from memory using the main data bus and the transfer is accomplished using DMA without CPU involvement. The northbridge handles the memory accesses, refreshes and all the high speed stuff. The northbridge handles the block DMA from the southbridge directly to memory without CPU intervention and informs the CPU when the transfer is complete. The southbridge handles the interface to the PCI bus which is much slower than the address/data bus to memory. 13 bridges? Your friend was pulling your leg. It is not a problem. What names did he give to these 13 bridges? Partial? Brooklyn? London? Tower? .... You have to plan some payback. 8-)

Message.Title: Intel Corporation Has Big Plans For Asia
Message.Msg: Intel Corporation has long viewed Asia as a manufacturing hub owing to the region’s vast market and low-cost labor. But the times are changing, with the expansion of region’s talent pool, Chip powerhouse now expects Asian engineers to help design processors that will be used in smartphones, tablets and PC’s. Intel’s Future Plans In a recent interview given to The Wall Street Journal, Robin Martin, vice president of Intel’s technology manufacturing group, and Christopher Kelly, head of Intel’s Malaysia Design Center, discussed the company’s plans in Asia. As per Mr. Martin, Asia is a huge market and is growing consistently. The logistics and infrastructure in the region is also improving, so “it makes sense for us to grow the seeds that we’ve sown here.” Presently, the Malaysian facility is responsible for chips used in smartphones, tablets, and SOCs (system on chips), but as the numbers grow, the company plans to rope in Vietnam because of the cost structure there. Intel Corporation employs around 2,000 engineers in Malaysia, 3,000 engineers in India, 3000 engineers in China and 1000 in Taiwan. These are the regions where “our rapidly growing markets are” says Mr. Kelly. Each of the facilities is capable of performing tasks from “design to manufacturing test with a slight twist.” Bangalore team design work for servers while the team at Penang do chipsets and central processing units. Chinese unit is involved in the platform and software developments, reveals Mr. Kelly. According to Mr. Martin, the bulk of the hiring will be in Vietnam as the company is “starting to move more of our SOCs products there.” Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC) has around 1000 engineers in Vietnam and plans to increase it to 4000 once the process is fully ramped up. From valuewalk

Message.Title: Pack Your Bags, ARM
Message.Msg: Pack your bags If Bay Trail's numbers prove to be indicative of real-world performance, there is little, if any incentive for Microsoft Corporation (NASDAQ:MSFT) to keep supporting Windows RT. Windows RT has been responsible for mass consumer confusion, and it lacks the backwards-compatibility with legacy Windows applications since it runs on ARM architecture. If Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC)'s products can outperform ARM and match its power consumption, Microsoft Corporation (NASDAQ:MSFT) would effectively have the green light to eliminate Windows RT altogether. This would allow Microsoft to further streamline the Windows 8 user experience and could potentially translate into improved reception. Unfortunately, from ARM's perspective, the Windows on ARM opportunity may be gone before it's arrived. The bigger picture Not only will Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC) be making a splash on the Windows side of things, it will also be working to grow its market share on the Android ecosystem. Although Android is known to be processor architecture agnostic, Intel remains disadvantaged against the ARM competition since existing Android apps aren't primarily optimized for Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC)'s x86 architecture. The hope is that Bay Trail's expected boost in performance will compensate for any performance hindrances this discrepancy may cause. Additionally, if Intel begins to gain meaningful Android market share, Android developers could begin to make the switch and start programming specifically for Intel's x86 architecture. Aside from how Intel performs on Android in the real world, you could always get excited about those $200 Bay Trail-powered Windows 8 tablets on the horizon. The article Intel Bay Trail Smokes the Quad-Core Competition is written by Steve Heller. From insidermonkey

Message.Title: Nokia Does The Right Thing, Ditches Windows RT
Message.Msg: Article from Ashraf Eassa: partial: "Anyway, so it seems that Nokia (NOK), Microsoft's best friend in the world, is dropping plans for a Windows RT tablet and is instead doing the smart thing and releasing a full Windows 8 tablet, likely based on Intel's upcoming "Bay Trail" platform. I believe that this could be Nokia's shot at not only becoming relevant in the tablet market, but it could propel the firm to a market leader in this space. Why Windows RT Makes No Sense Windows RT - the OS, not the underlying runtime engine for the Metro UI - plain sucks. Contrary to popular belief, not everybody wants to replace a full Windows PC with a much more limited mobile OS. People like to print to their printers, use their traditional USB peripherals, run desktop applications, play their classic video games, and essentially have the best of both worlds. The unique advantage that Windows 8 has over any other platform is that in the "Metro" mode, it's a very competent tablet-oriented OS, but when real work needs to be done, a quick tap gets you into the full desktop" [A Nokia tablet running Bay Trail sounds good!]
